description.narrative: Resilience Stabilization/Durable Solution for the Joint State Liaison Function (SLF) throughout Darfur

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of productive infructructure rehabilitated/ constructed by State /by type 1.2 Number of people accessing infructure and livelihoods opportunities by gender; 1.3 Number of of Joint Management Commitees established. 2.1 Number of RRR/DS Coordinators seconded to Voluntary Return and Recovery Commission (VRRC) 2.2 Number of RR/DS coordination meetings organized 2.3 Number of verification and assessment missions organised 2.4 Number of consultation workshops and capacity development trainings conducted; 2.5 % increase in the ability of VRRC to coordinate DS stakeholders in managing land issues. 3.1 # of people trained in vocational skills 3.2 # of peole trained in entreprenership 3.3 # of people received start-up kits 3.4 # of youth centers constructed 3.5 #of youth centers provided with sanitation facilities. 4.1 # of value chain associations established/reactivated. 4.2 Total conflict-free agricultural land area made available to returness (ha) 4.3 # of people accessing agricultural production inputs and extension service 4.4 # of farmers linked to output market. 5.1 # of voluntary savings and lending associations established 5.2 # of people trained on micor- enterprise development 5.3 # of people accessing business start-up grants 5.4 # of people trained on Darfur microfinance APEX. 6.1 # of Producer groups established on poultry and cheese 6.2 # of producer groups trained on poultry and cheese production methods 6.3 # of producer groups accessing production tools/equipment on poultry and cheese 6.4 # of Rural Livelihood hubs established.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Promoting social cohesion between farmers, pastoralists & returnee communities in 8 localities of East, South and West Darfur along the migratory routes through water, health, education and livelihood activities; Targets: 1.1 7 productive infrastructures rehabilitated/ constructed by State /by type 1.2 At least 2000 people accessing infrastructures and livelihoods opportunities by gender; 1.3 At least 7 Joint Management Committees established
Output 2: Capacity building and institutional strengthening of the VRRC for Durable Solutions Coordination Targets: 2.1 3 RRR/DS Coordinators seconded to VRRC 2.2 15 RR/DS coordination meetings organized 2.3 4 Verification meetings supported 2.4 10 consultation workshops and capacity development trainings conducted;
Output 3: Construction of Youth Centres, provision of vocational and entrepreneurship training and alternative employment to target at-risk youth. Targets: 3.1 200 people trained in vocational skills 3.2 100 people trained in entrepreneurship 3.3 200 people received start-up kits 3.4 one youth centres constructed and furnished; 3.5 Youth centre provided with sanitation facilities.
Output 4: Support Self-Reliance for Sustainable Return and Peaceful Reintegration of IDPs Targets 4.1 8 of value chain associations established 4.2 At least 2000 ha of conflict-free agricultural land area made available to returnees (ha) 4.3 At least 2000 of people accessing agricultural production inputs and extension service 4.4 2000 of farmers linked to output market
Output 5: Support access to micro-finance for improved livelihood among vulnerable IDP and returnee producers, especially vulnerable women. Targets 5.1 20 voluntary savings and lending associations established 5.2 500 people trained on micro-enterprise development: 5.3 200 people accessing business start-up grants
Output 6: Rural Livelihoods Support to improve social cohesion Targets 6.1 20 Producer groups established 6.2 20 producer groups trained on production methods 6.3 2000 households accessing production tools/equipment 6.4 2 Rural Livelihood hubs established

Results 2019: 1.1 Joint assessments were conducted by UNDP and partners in the targeted areas in all the four states for identification and prioritization of locations, infrastructure, livelihood activities and opportunities, and agreement on target groups and to avoid duplication. 1.1 The construction and equipping of One (1) multi-purpose livelihood center in Al Neem, in El Daein, East Darfur is complete. Also, one (1) Livelihoods Centre has been rehabilitated in Umsebeigah in West Darfur State. The centers are now being used for various community activities as well as livelihoods activities by women and youth. 1.1 UNDP rehabilitated/ constructed 8 productive infrastructures including one major dam in Mulm Alwedian in Daresalam locality in North, boreholes and irrigation dam and seven (7) boreholes in East, and West Darfur. 1.1 200 hectares of land has been prepared for 400 smallholder returnee farmers for irrigated cultivation. Activities include production of certified land preparation and extension services, vegetables and planting of 4,500 trees to protect the banks of the dam. 1.2 A total of 4,131 vulnerable households (45 percent women) were supported with various productive inputs and training in North, West and East Darfur to enable them to engage in livelihood activities around livelihood centers and water resources. 1.3 Eight (8) Joint Management Committees (JMCs), composed of 40% females, were established and trained on conflict management in East Darfur, North Darfur, and West Darfur to ensure equitable and sustainable use of water resources to curb conflict among competing communities over access to natural resources and basic social services.
2.1 Three (3) RRR/DS coordinators were recruited to work closely with the VRRC and the State RRR Sectors to coordinate Return and Reintegration process as the dominant Durable Solution. 2.2 ICT equipment including desktop computers, printers and photocopiers have been procured and are being distributed to the VRRC offices in four states; North, South, East, and West Darfur. Additionally, offices of the VRRC were renovated. 2.2 A total of 31 Returns and Reintegration (RRR) sector coordination meetings were held in the 4 States (North, South, East, Central and West Darfur) involving all key stakeholders within the Government, AHCT and UNCT. 2.3 Twenty (20) Verification and Assessment Missions were organized in North, South, East, Central, and West Darfur bringing all stakeholders together to assess and verify the number of IDPs returning into target locations, their needs, obstacles to sustainable reintegration, among others. 2.4 Two (2) State level consultation workshops were conducted with the participation of 80 stakeholders from the state level Eight (8) additional local level consultation workshops and capacity development trainings on land management were organized in collaboration with the Darfur Land Commission and the VRRC.
3.1 Over 405 at-risk youth from North and South Darfur received vocational skill training. In North Darfur, 200 at-risk youth received vocational skill training. Out of the 200 people trained, 80 were women. In South Darfur, 205 (85 women and 180 men) received vocational skill training. 3.2 All the youth (405) were taken through entrepreneurship trainings in North and South Darfur. 3.3 Start-up kits were provided to all the 405 trainees after the completion of vocational training and graduation ceremonies have been held. 3.4 One (1) Youth Center has been rehabilitated in Umsebeigha return village and one new Youth Center constructed in El Genina in West Darfur. The Youth Centres rehabilitation using 12,000 SSB were produced for the construction of the two centres. Vocational training in the state is being facilitated through the existing and already-equipped vocational centers.
4.1.1 The project worked with various implementing partners in North, South, East, and West Darfur to select new value chains building on existing value chains. 4.1.2 The project established/reactivated 16 value chain associations in North and East Darfur and trained them to pursue different on-farm and off-farm activities in groundnuts and sesame production. 4.1.3 In North Darfur, the Project established/reactivated four (4) producer groups; two (2) producer groups each for sesame, sorghum and groundnuts in Darelsalam and Malam Elwedian. 4.1.4 In East Darfur, twelve (12) Groundnut producer groups were established with membership of 300 households. The associations were trained in Good Agricultural Practices (GAPs). In South Darfur, 5 Groundnut producer Associations have been established and supported. 4.2 UNDP has facilitated access to 1,086.25 hectares of conflict-free and productive land in the North, South, and East Darfur. In North Darfur 808 hectares were made available to more than 700 farmers (IDPs and return communities). In South Darfur, 168 hectares of conflict-free land made available with support from DRFOOD. In East Darfur, 12 Groundnut Producer Associations supported with ploughing, improved seeds and tools covering 110.25 hectares for about 300 vulnerable households. 4.3.1 More than 5,000 vulnerable farmers in North, South, East and West Darfur States were supported with productive inputs. A total of 1,280 hectares were under cultivation of improved seeds (68 metric tons) of food crops and vegetables. 4.3.2 Over 4,000 vulnerable returnees and host households were supported through capacity building and access to productive inputs to engage in commercial production in the above commodities in linkage with private industries (DARFOOD). 4.3.3 In North Darfur 8 metric tons of foundation seeds of sesame, sorghum, and groundnuts were procured to plant 84 hectares certified seeds under supplementary irrigation. A total of 150 metric tons of improved seeds of sesame, sorghum, and groundnuts will be produced for distribution to 5,000 new returnees, IDPs in 2020. Additionally, 2,200 vulnerable households in Kornoi and Um Baru were supported with vegetable seeds to increase off season livelihood activities under valley bottom farming. Also, 240 farmers (agro-pastoralist) in Kornoi locality received agricultural hand tools. 4.3.4 In East Darfur, 300 groundnut producers involving 12 VSLA benefited from improved groundnut seeds and tools. Each group received 720kg of improved groundnut seeds cultivating 6.72 hectares. 4.3.5 In West Darfur, 260 Farmer Associations, 50% females, involving 20 groundnut producer associations benefited from 24 metric tons of improved certified groundnut and donkey ploughs. 4.3.6 Extension services provided to over 1,746 farmers in all the four states of Darfur through the establishment of demonstration farms and Farmer and Nomadic Field Schools (FNFS). 4.3.7 A number of 965 groundnut farmers trained on afla-toxin management in North, East, and West Darfur (North Darfur, 600 farmers (40 percent women); East Darfur 250 framers and West Darfur 105 farmers (28 men and 77 women).
4.4.1 In South and East Darfur, UNDP is implementing a Private Sector Partnership model to provided financing for agricultural inputs and technical assistance to farmers on agreed terms where farmers produce to feed a factory - Darfood. Five Associations have been assisted under this scheme in West and East Darfur States. 4.4.2 The project provided access to market for 4000 members of Producer Associations in North, East, South and West Darfur. All trainings offered to farmers incorporated how to access different markets. Agreement was signed with DARFOOD for market access for 146 farmers (15 percent women) producing groundnuts, sorghum and sesame.
5.1 Forty (40) Voluntary Savings and Lending Associations (VSLAs) made up of 1,1031 members (789 women, 242 men) were established, trained on marketing, microfinance, and principles of setting up small businesses and supported with registration and capacity building. 5.2 430 individuals (involving 86 households) with women representing 57 % received 4 days training on Darfur microfinance APEX on access to microfinance credit. Four (4) villages within two villages Tarbiba and Masteri in Beida locality and Umsebeigha and Deliba in Geneina locality. 5.3 37 VSLAs received micro-grants to start income-generating activities whilst increasing their own savings mobilization for continued internal lending. The use of the VSLA modality has also improved interactions between members of different communities thereby building confidence and trust.
6.1 A number 32 Cheese and Poultry Producer Associations established. 6.2 A number 32 Cheese and Poultry Producer Associations trained in North, East and West Darfur. 6.3 A total of 536 producer association members, 56 percent women, benefited from training and start-up kits. 6.4 Two (2) rural livelihood hubs had been constructed in North Darfur localities of Kornoi and Sarafayia. In Kornoi, the rural livelihood hub will serve as a processing center for cheese as well as veterinary center for the treatment and control of livestock diseases for nomads. In Sarafayia, the livelihood hub, amongst other activities, will support the production of vegetables, processing and other income generation activities as well as veterinary services.
The project has been operationally closed and no activities planned in 2022.
The project has been operationally closed and no activities planned in 2022.
The project has no planned activities in 2020.
The project has no planned activities in 2020.
The project has no planned activities in 2021.
The project has no planned activities in 2021.
